description:
With these changes, an installed yt (haven't yet gotten it to be single-codebase) gives me 15 test errors, 74 failures, mostly due to arithmetic changes I think.

Not yet ready, but nearly.

UPDATE 14JAN2015: I've updated this with the 3.1 release, and started looking at it again.  Now using Python 3.4.2 to build.  Currently, 24 errors, 69 failures.
title: [WIP] Second set of Python 3 fixes

content.raw:
This is awesome, thanks for the work on this Matt!

Your comment in the PR description intrigued me: Is single-codebase a goal?
content.html:
This is awesome, thanks for the work on this Matt!

Your comment in the PR description intrigued me: Is single-codebase a goal?

content.raw:
Thanks!  And, I am not yet sure.  The main issue I think is going to be
string formatting.  I'm not really interested in using the future module,
but we have six, so it might be feasible.  I think the
bytes/strings/formatting stuff might be the biggest hangup.
content.html: Thanks! And, I am not yet sure. The main issue I think is going to be string formatting. I'm not really interested in using the future module, but we have six, so it might be feasible. I think the bytes/strings/formatting stuff might be the biggest hangup.

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_testing/1279/

Thanks for working on this! I use Python 3.4 for production work, so looking forward to this :)

A single code-base is nice, but it is a fair amount of work. You could always first support Python with 2to3 and only then slowly transition to a single code base.
content.html:
Thanks for working on this! I use Python 3.4 for production work, so looking forward to this :)

A single code-base is nice, but it is a fair amount of work. You could always first support Python with 2to3 and only then slowly transition to a single code base.

content.raw: Matt, where in these changes do you expect to find arithmetic changes that result in the errors/failures?
content.html: Matt, where in these changes do you expect to find arithmetic changes that result in the errors/failures?

content.raw:
@mzingale mostly in division changes.  I am not 100% certain why they have
changed.  Fortunately, they're being caught.
content.html: Michael Zingale mostly in division changes. I am not 100% certain why they have changed. Fortunately, they're being caught.

content.raw: it's not the bit about python 3 doing integer division different than 2, is it?
content.html: it's not the bit about python 3 doing integer division different than 2, is it?

content.raw:
Yes, *but*, we were really careful about that in the past.  I think there
is a side effect of a rounding issue which touches our slicing.
content.html: Yes, but, we were really careful about that in the past. I think there is a side effect of a rounding issue which touches our slicing.

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_testing/1295/

My plan once this is working and passes all the tests is to decline this PR, graft the first two changesets on, then apply the diff from the PR on a few directories at a time.  This will keep the commits relatively atomic and make bisection much easier.
content.html: My plan once this is working and passes all the tests is to decline this PR, graft the first two changesets on, then apply the diff from the PR on a few directories at a time. This will keep the commits relatively atomic and make bisection much easier.

All tests pass. Good job!
Woohoo!
Does this mean that yt now supports python 3?
content.html: Does this mean that yt now supports python 3?

content.raw: Minor nit: is this conditional necessary?
Is this file being included intentionally?
Woop Woop!!

It means that the python2 tests pass and that it's probably safe to merge this PR now.

We won't be able to guarantee python3 support until we have testing set up using python3.4.
content.html:
It means that the python2 tests pass and that it's probably safe to merge this PR now.

We won't be able to guarantee python3 support until we have testing set up using python3.4.

content.raw: I'm guessing this will be relaxed in the future.
content.html: I'm guessing this will be relaxed in the future.

content.raw:
Besides the nits below, LGTM.

Should we think about importing `absolute_import` and `print_function` from `__future__` across the whole codebase?
content.html:
Besides the nits below, LGTM.

Should we think about importing absolute_import and print_function from __future__ across the whole codebase?

content.raw: Not in this PR, but potentially in a future update.
content.html: Not in this PR, but potentially in a future update.

content.raw: Nope, it's not; when I changed it I missed it.  Will remove conditional, thanks!
content.html: Nope, it's not; when I changed it I missed it. Will remove conditional, thanks!

content.raw: I hope so -- I didn't see this -- @jnaiman I think added it on my suggestion.
content.html: I hope so -- I didn't see this -- Jill Naiman I think added it on my suggestion.

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_testing/1888/
This appears to be the heisenbug-ish halo finding answer test thing again.
content.html: This appears to be the heisenbug-ish halo finding answer test thing again.

content.raw: I ran @MatthewTurk 's `python3` bookmark version using python 2.x on a 3-d dataset examining the fields, plotting a line through the data. doing phase plots, volume rendering, and extracting a surface and everything looked like it should.
content.html: I ran Matthew Turk 's python3 bookmark version using python 2.x on a 3-d dataset examining the fields, plotting a line through the data. doing phase plots, volume rendering, and extracting a surface and everything looked like it should.

content.raw: Should definitely be the latter, yup.

doing an `install` as @MatthewTurk suggested, I can import this into python3 (I'm running python 3.4.1).  When I try a volume rendering, my script works fine in python2 but barfs with python3:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./vol.py", line 133, in <module>
    doit(plotfile, fname)
  File "./vol.py", line 87, in doit
    fields = [field], log_fields = [use_log])
  File "/home/zingale/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py3.4-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/visualization/volume_rendering/camera.py", line 194, in __init__
    efields = dd._determine_fields(self.fields)
  File "/home/zingale/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py3.4-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/data_containers.py", line 494, in _determine_fields
    finfo = self.ds._get_field_info(ftype, fname)
  File "/home/zingale/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py3.4-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/static_output.py", line 448, in _get_field_info
    self.index
  File "/home/zingale/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py3.4-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/static_output.py", line 283, in index
    self.create_field_info()
  File "/home/zingale/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py3.4-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/static_output.py", line 328, in create_field_info
    self.field_info.setup_fluid_fields()
  File "/home/zingale/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py3.4-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/frontends/boxlib/fields.py", line 280, in setup_fluid_fields
    if field[3] in string.letters:
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'letters'
```
content.html:
doing an install as Matthew Turk suggested, I can import this into python3 (I'm running python 3.4.1). When I try a volume rendering, my script works fine in python2 but barfs with python3:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./vol.py", line 133, in <module>
    doit(plotfile, fname)
  File "./vol.py", line 87, in doit
    fields = [field], log_fields = [use_log])
  File "/home/zingale/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py3.4-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/visualization/volume_rendering/camera.py", line 194, in __init__
    efields = dd._determine_fields(self.fields)
  File "/home/zingale/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py3.4-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/data_containers.py", line 494, in _determine_fields
    finfo = self.ds._get_field_info(ftype, fname)
  File "/home/zingale/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py3.4-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/static_output.py", line 448, in _get_field_info
    self.index
  File "/home/zingale/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py3.4-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/static_output.py", line 283, in index
    self.create_field_info()
  File "/home/zingale/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py3.4-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/data_objects/static_output.py", line 328, in create_field_info
    self.field_info.setup_fluid_fields()
  File "/home/zingale/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/yt-3.2dev-py3.4-linux-x86_64.egg/yt/frontends/boxlib/fields.py", line 280, in setup_fluid_fields
    if field[3] in string.letters:
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'letters'

content.raw:
looks like we need ascii_letters

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9561432/what-is-the-equivalence-in-python-3-of-letters-in-python-2
All tests pass. Good job!
